author: @justsaychloe1060
text:
My roommate and I were at the Seattle Space Needle shutdown for Palestine when this video went up. She's been a semi-frequent volunteer at Food Not Bombs since she was fourteen, and I have been a member of the DSA for nearly two years. I sat with this video for awhile. If I can rant candidly, then I want you and others in this comment section to know how valuable this has been for me.

I am an Asian-Pacific Islander mixed, dual-citizenship immigrant, a Jewish convert, and a transgender woman. I turn twenty into three months. I consider myself well-read, yet I dropped out of college to better support my family. Infinite indescribable things inform my worldview, but I have taken the last year (especially the last eighty-seven days) to relearn my real, tangible socio-political impact, and your video was like a breath of fresh air. Particularly the section on revolution versus civic engagement, for I have always struggled with my desire to be a "burn it all down" martyr while surrounded by frustrating people that claim this mantle without actually risking anything. Your video made me realise that there's a reason I'm frustrated; we (including myself) have not been honest with ourselves on how my circle is better suited for civic engagement roles, and it may be more productive to lean into that rather than constantly fighting myself to perform (key word) revolutionary acts. This conclusion comes after a lot of introspection taking from lots of reading, but you put it best. It's a surprisingly-targeted, relieving insight to take away from a stranger on the Internet. Thank you for your lived experience and your effort in being understanding and direct.

Also, while many other commenters have already espoused it, the later sections on how our fight is a forever-struggle for the people against the government and how it is useful to think about the Democrats and Republicans as differing opponents rather than bettering proponents of change has provided me with the words to better explain my burgeoning perspective on voting and running for offices. The elections are very quiet in Washington state, which is paradoxically both densely urban and also devoid of community (some call it the Seattle Freeze, others call it the aftershocks of racial residential segregation), so heaps of our reliably-blue candidates run largely unopposed. Also, I'm young and couldn't vote for a long time. Nevertheless, I distinctively remember us nearly turning red in the 2016 Presidential election, and I remember my brother's white fianc√©e complaining about the election being stolen even then. And Trump won anyway. It has since been a long debate between my colleagues and I on the "Democrats and Republicans are the same" point, and it is refreshing to be able to pull from F.D. Signifier, Marc Lamont Hill, and others' words here as well. You have brought together a respectable consideration for "vote blue no matter who", and it is something I am excited to share with my friends.

Recently, I have quietly come to extreme altruism in hopes of building a better, interlocked community. I have been houseless, starved, and criminalised before; I cannot be scared of that anymore, so I consider myself still willing to risk everything to be "that" militant-revolutionary. Further, I cannot compromise my beliefs in shouting from rooftops "Genocide Joe has got to go" and "Biden, Biden, you're a liar" until my body collapses, just to turn around and vote for him without witnessing a tangible acquiescence to ending U.S. aid to Israel. Yet this video (and many others) has grounded me in being realistic with my abilities and goals, and it reminds me that the world is in constant genocide whether U.S. funding is publicly involved or not. And, as an immigrant privileged with citizenship and considerable proximity to whiteness, the amount of time spent on immigration as a life-or-death struggle was extremely appreciated. This video is inspiring, valuable, and respectable. Thank you again.

Free Palestine, free all colonised people. Peace upon us all in the new year and forever onwards. Cheers, Olly!

replies.text: @ianneal7667keep reading and learning and pay attention to local politics. When I was in high school I got involved in keeping one of our library branches open. We were successful and even got the local Eagle Scouts to build a playground there and it really improved the community. That kind of stuff is a wedge you can use to nudge people towards progressivism. It takes it out of the realm of left vs right and into the realm of tangible changes they can see locally.

replies.text: @ianneal7667when my boomer mom was about your age she joined a protest against a nuclear power plant being built in Manhattan and her dad (my grandfather) freaked out because he worked at Long Island lighting CO at the time.. she still to this day refuses to vote and be active in politics because of it.. don‚Äôt let your parents (who usually vote on financial interests they perceive to benefit them) stop you from holding your own beliefs and fighting for what‚Äôs right.. every good change has come from the youth. When you are young and have no money interests you are purely driven by what‚Äôs in your heart and what feels right morally. The hard part is staying true to those values and learning a strong foundation of exactly why you believe them so you can‚Äôt be shaken by some contrived media crap or some fool pushing right wing bullshit. You are already on a good path because you are clearly not just parroting your parents talking points and following in their foot steps.

replies.author: @SNESpool
replies.text:
Damage mitigation. We live in a system where theres only two parties in power, both are bad in their own ways, but one party is easier for we the people to exert our influence over. The Dems haven't done nearly enough, but they've shown at least that they're willing to make concessions to the left, if they believe the decision will be popular (and that's something we, as citizens, have a lot of power to influence. 

The GOP, on the other hand, has understood for decades already that their goals and views are unpopular, and they are going to pursue them anyway, at any cost, regardless of what the public wants. 

So that's the choice: a party that is hesitant to wield state power (even when it should) and, for all its flaws, has proven that it is at least _open_ to changing with the tides of public opinion... 

and then a party that actively, vehemently opposes the will of the people, and has shown nothing but contempt for the people it means to govern, and has proven beyond a shadow of a doubt that it will use ANY means necessary to achieve its incredibly _un_popular goals. 

Morally righteous politicians don't exist. The best possibility under this system, is to elect politicians who find it to be _in their own best interests_ to listen to the will of the people. 
@MachilaWilson-ii3qm

replies.author: @SNESpool
replies.text: It's something I've been trying to articulate for years, only spoken more eloquently than I could ever hope to.

replies.author: @MachilaWilson-ii3qm
replies.text: @SNESpool You say that the Dems hardly did enough. Exactly what have they specifically done that exclusively helped Black Americans as a collective like they have for the Jews, LGBT, illegal immigrants, Native Americans, Ukraine and Afghanistan?

replies.author: @AnEntropyFan
replies.text:
@olurinatti 
In general and in principle an agreeable video and a noble motivation. However one, although very passing quote, is bad enough that it ought to be corrected and the source taken as highly suspicious in your future research. Specifically, the source you are reading out about US imperialism is straight lying to people who might not know the details. 

The cited part that I do know quite about is the Kosovo War. The bombing of Yugoslavia did not kill 8000 civilians nor did it displace a million people. The bombing killed few hundred civilians (and 2-3 times military personnel, the civilians were killed mostly as collateral damage tho there were isolated cases, quite literally a handful, where civilians were targeted), while displacing practically no one. The misrepresented numbers you are quoting are the casualties of the Kosovo War in its entirety, also not quite right for whichever reason since the estimates of the casualties are more like in the 10000-15000 ballpark (depending on how we treat the "missing", I'd confidently argue they're gone gone, and the discrepancies in sources). 

The war, starting in 1998, was a culmination of non-militarised state oppression of the Albanian minority in Serbia, quite similar to what Israel is doing right now to the Palestinians (the one difference is that Milosevic stripped regional autonomy and tried to create apartheid conditions in the then Serbian province and now the Republic of Kosovo, while Israel escalated from apartheid conditions). Under the auspices of fighting an Albanian nationalist insurgency, which formed in responce to the aforementioned state oppression, the Milosevic regime took it as an opportunity to launch a large scale genocidal campaign. The campaign ramped up as the US bombing started since Milosevic had to do it quickly at that point (and hope he'd get to get away with it and keep the territorial gains, just like his Bosnian Christian proxies did at the end of the Bosnian War, a war which the US could've stopped but Bill Clinton decided he wanted a second term instead and let 200K people die as the UN watched and clutched pearls), but the intent and the methods have been there from the start. The bulk of the killed and exiled (and the bulk of the Albanian population was displaced at one point, sot the cited number is in the correct ballpark) are the victims of Milosevic's forces, most notably victims of a terror campaign conducted by elite police paramilitaries directly tied to the regime that included things like summary exctns. 

Be careful when quoting "socialist" sources, because there are socialists and then there are "socialists"; there are anti-imperialists and then there are "anti-imperialists". Of course it's not reasonable to expect that you'd hold the details on a random conflict from decades ago in your head, however when a source is pointed out as dishonest it should be dropped with extreme prejudice and better care taken from now on.

author: @1fareast14
text: For all the performativity put on blast in this video, non-voters do a lot of this too. When they say that both parties are the same, they often mean "I dont have to care about other people", or "Disengaged learned helplessness is more comfortable than conscious terror at the news" or "Im voting Trump but I know I can't defend it". People have gotten way harder to talk to over my lifetime because they don't say what they mean.

author: @LivingMonae
text: Bravo on a truly phenomenal piece of work. As a Black Woman who was so proud to vote when I turned 18 and now 36 have descended into complete dissolution with the 2 party system and gave up on voting. I can truly say you‚Äôve reminded me of why I was proud to vote in the first place. Why my right to vote is so important and why it‚Äôs imperative that I participate in, not only federal elections, but my local ones as well. I am committing to participating in the political process and doing so in an informed way. It‚Äôs the least I can do for myself and all Americans. Thank you

As an American, I'll tell you that Starmer is so, so much worse than Biden. Biden's foreign policy, specifically on Israel, is downright diabolical, but on domestic matters he's been somewhat willing to distance himself from the neoliberalism of Obama and Clinton, such as him being the first president to cross a picket line.

Starmer is what a lot of whiny anti-voting "leftists" in America think Biden is. He is a straight up Red Tory who makes Tony Blair look like Tony Benn.

text: I really appreciate what you said about Twitter! It really is the opposite of what I learned in academia. I‚Äôve rarely seen anyone quote tweet something like ‚ÄúI have some critiques of this person‚Äôs thread but this one idea reality inspired me to think.‚Äù The internet interferes with critical thinking in so many ways it‚Äôs is easy to lose track. I really need to keep reminding myself that I am in the pursuit of knowledge, not the pursuit of building up rage or sad facts that confirm my despair or feeling smarter than other people. The way the everyday commercial internet is set up is really the opposite of what is useful or enriching.

author: @WolfsDE
text:
I am glad that you did address the vote shaming aspect. To me, the reason vote shaming does not work is for the same reason telling a 13 year old kid not to be on an adult website doesn't actually work. 

That kid is going to be like....hey...I was told no. I want to see why even more now. Just natural curiosity goes up when told no. 

Same effect happens with movies and TV shows and video games and music. If a bunch of people are screaming no about it...everyone else is going to want to take part, even if for no other reason than to Troll the ones saying no. 

A vote is earned. It is not something that can or should ever be thought of as a given. 

I am not black. I am sure the way I am writing this will give it away. I am transgender. Yes, there are real consequences for if I vote, if I don't vote or who I vote for. 

I have had a hard time with voting because of feeling disenfranchised a lot, having my name tossed off the register 3 times, being told that I am some horrible monster because how dare I not bow down and support X person and I don't deserve the right to vote because of it. 

It gets insane. To the point where I honestly have no hope for this world. Not just the USA, but the entire world. 

I am watching as we went from fighting the goose steppers in my grandparents generation to our country wanting to be them. 

I honest worry that no matter what happens this year,  if Trump ends up in prison, as POTUS or P.I.P. (President in Prison) or loses in November,  the outcome is going to be really damn bad. 

Because I fully believe any outcome starts a civil war.  

I also believe if we continue down this path we are on, we might be seeing World War 3 as well. So, any hope for peace, pretty much is gone in my books. 

I wish I knew the answer. 

I hate the notion of vote blue no matter who though. I think vote for a label first is dangerous.  Now, granted, I would never want to vote for any of these jackals trying to claim the party of Lincoln.  They stopped being the party of Lincoln a hell of a long time ago. 

My point is only that if my choices are vote for Charles Manson or Jeffrey Dahmer, then the only vote should be for what gun to use on them both at that point. It can't ever be a "no matter who" situation.  

We always have to be mindful of who is running is my point. 

But I do agree. Trump more than anyone else represents a clear and present danger to the USA and to the World.  To not stand up and try to stop him would be a moral failing.  I don't know how much it might be the right thing to vote for Biden it really is, but I do know to not vote Trump down especially,  could be the end of the country.  

It could be that no matter what happens, it is the end of the country. 



I haven't finished this video and may add more in, might not.

author: @cerumen
text:
This is the first video of yours I‚Äôve seen, not even halfway through, and while I don‚Äôt agree with absolutely everything everyone said, it‚Äôs‚Ä¶frankly incredibly refreshing

It‚Äôs not a critical analysis of a niche pop culture artefact, there are no oblique references to obscure revolutionary history, it‚Äôs a not a ‚Äúand that‚Äôs why capitalism bad!‚Äù. I didn‚Äôt get the familiar feeling of being patronised, judged, talked down to, or manipulated. There was no indulgent cruelty or malice toward anyone or anything. No staring into the miserable bowels of the abyss for the purpose of dunk farming. No giant deep dive into a dispiriting doomhole only to conclude ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have any answers, but‚Ä¶‚Äù No poorly researched, sloppily scripted, lazily delivered high school video essay content. No in-jokes, no confusing metanarrative framing device. No vague utopian fantasy.

Just people passionately advocating things that make practical pragmatic sense, in a way that makes a person feel empowered. Why does that feel so new?

author: @doodelay
text:
I appreciate all the work you put into the video, my friend sent this to me and we discussed. There's a variety of issues I had with some of the points made here but I think my thoughts can be summarized by saying that if one acknowledges that the Democrats are getting more conservative with every election cycle, on all issues but social issues, then it is obvious that voting blue no matter who will inevitably bring us to the same place that the Republicans have brought us to now. 

And why? 

You touched very lightly on the fact that both parties work for the same corporate interests although this should've been at the forefront of the discussion imo. And clearly corporate America doesn't care either way if we remain an oligarchy or transition to authoritarianism, and they certainly don't care if that transition takes place quickly under Republicans or slowly under Democrats. 

And that is what's going on, if you ignore the interests of Corporate America you will continue to think that there's at least one party fighting to keep democracy, which is the crux of the entire debate. 
And the Democrats have made it abundantly clear to everyone watching that "saving democracy" isn't their top priority, otherwise they'd open the primaries up and allow a challenge to a deeply unpopular Biden. 

But they don't, and this shows that they're already exhibiting strong elements of authoritarianism as it is, thus, threatening to withhold the vote unless we get a real and vibrant primary is the only civic strategy worth having at this time, along with popularizing rank choice voting.

At 2:19:50 you present the boulder analogy of liberation at the top of a hill. My question to you is if Republicans symbolize gravity, pulling against our efforts, which direction do you think the democratic party is pushing? Is it up the hill with us, or are they assisting gravity pushing against us? And somewhat separately, do you believe that genocide isn't fascism?

Finally, to respond to your latter comments on why do we do activism at all if we truly believe the two parties are the same. 

I do feel that both establishment parties are the same under the union of corporate interests, but there is a tiny but growing faction of the democratic party since Bernie Sanders that is actively working with us. And that's the element in American politics that makes civic engagement like withholding the vote worth pursuing, for now, imo.

author: @ynat2198
text:
First off OKAY! thank you for putting in so much in to this simply so that we as the viewer could make informed decisions. Thank you to you, to those that gave their voices and input and time and energy solely to put information out in to the world during this election year. 
I'm a first gen immigrant, voting was always something that the family was divided on. We come from a country that has been and continues to be directly affected by US elections. Why should i vote here when my own country, Pakistan, has been denied fair and open elections by this very system? Where the only viable option was jailed at the behest of this govt with a carrot of aide dangling in front?  I struggle every time the word ‚Äúvoting‚Äù comes up. 
  My father, who SO believes in the act of voting regardless of outcome, continues to hold out hope (for what, i don't think even he knows). I am going to be honest i don't know if i care enough to vote simply to have to then drum up enough energy AGAIN to fight a weak mentally immobile president and his/ her ilk. 
Regardless thank you for your work. üôèüèΩ

author: @cwillott
text:
Thank you for making this video. I'm one of your white fan base. First saw you on The Leftist Mafia, then subscribed to your YouTube & Twitter accounts. As a result of having campaigned for Bernie in 2016 & 2020, I became a delegate to the California Democratic Party and have invested much time & energy into local elections in my politically conservative community to move our leadership leftward. It's a slow brutal process that we have to work on repeatedly. 
It's great that you included Nina Turner here. She's been inspirational to me. It was heartbreaking to campaign for her House run in 2021 only to see it stolen away at the last minute by dark money smears.

text:
Got through the whole thing, and I gotta say this may be the single best overview on voting I've ever seen! You're empathetic yet don't pull punches. We've all got choices to make, and it's about acknowledging the inherent compromise of voting rather than thinking any candidate will be the end all be all solution.

I'm gonna use that "weakest adversary" point in my own advocacy and share this in my organizing. Love again!

author: @doublej7293
text: Incredible vid!!! I canvassed for Nina turner in her last run against shontel brown (establishment dem) and she was polling great w a fired up voter base but over a million dollars lobbied (from pro Israel pacs and other conservative and establishment dem pacs) behind shontel in the last month or so leading to her victory. That just really broke my heart honestly me and some friends put in the work for her grass roots campaign just for the system to rip her victory away. It‚Äôs been hard for me to get back into canvassing since then even tho I support Nina fully and don‚Äôt regret putting in that work having all that ripped away by the establishment has made me feel less hopeful to this. Awesome that you had Nina on :‚Äô(

author: @mayroque5296
text:
I vote because if by the slimmest margin we can bring about change without violent revolution then I prefer that. However in my heart of hearts and just my reading of history and looking at the situation in America I believe that as soon as progress truly threatens capitalism, the facade of democracy will be discarded.

But hope is not lost, vote if you want to but do contribute to your community, help form the bonds that can bring about the change for progress that we believe in outside of the structure.

author: @MissEliza99
text:
Thank you for this.  I really needed to hear what folks had to say in this video.  I had been really struggling with the idea of voting for Biden because of the support for genocide issue, but you laid out a cogent and compelling argument.  My husband is very relieved that you were able to succeed where he was having difficulty.  Lol.

My heart goes out to you with your immigration struggles, and I wish you all the best.  I hate how flippant and dismissive this country is about people's lives.  And I heard recently Biden and the Dems are negotiating shittier immigration policy in exchange for Ukraine funding?  What the actual fuck?  But, as you say, bad as they are, the alternative is worse.

Thank you for all your hard work, and I look forward to seeing what you have for 2024!

author: @JL-142
text: Localities are definitely their own story. The federal election in particular in 2024 is gonna be odd for me just cause participation feels like a tacit exoneration of our government's ability to enable genocide with little to no reapercussions. Ig in my mind there's a bigger statement in withholding your participation in certain contexts because it communicates you see the bs and aren't gonna give it a pass. Not this time. The convo is different with mayors, governors, actual acts you get to vote on for your state, etc.
